description:
Talaromyces marneffei ATCC 18224 is a species of filamentous fungi belonging to the genus Talaromyces. It is a thermally dimorphic fungus, meaning it can exist in both a mycelial form (at lower temperatures) and a yeast-like form (at higher temperatures, such as those found in the human host).

The ATCC 18224 strain is a reference strain that has been widely used in research and clinical settings. It is known to be a causative agent of the disease penicilliosis, which is an opportunistic infection that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.

Genetically, T. marneffei ATCC 18224 has been studied extensively, and its genome has been sequenced. This has provided insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying its dimorphic behavior, virulence factors, and pathogenicity.

In the laboratory, the fungus can be cultured on various media, and it exhibits characteristic features, such as the production of a distinctive red pigment and the formation of septate hyphae and conidiophores with phialides and conidia.

Overall, T. marneffei ATCC 18224 is an important model organism for the study of fungal dimorphism, pathogenesis, and the development of antifungal therapies, particularly in the context of opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals.
